I got fail2ban to work on 
/etc/fail2ban/action.d/iptables-multiport-drop.conf
```
# Fail2Ban configuration file
#
# Author: Cyril Jaquier
# Modified by Yaroslav Halchenko for multiport banning
#

[INCLUDES]

before = iptables-common.conf

[Definition]

# Option:  actionstart
# Notes.:  command executed on demand at the first ban (or at the start of Fail2Ban if actionstart_on_demand is set to false).
# Values:  CMD
#
actionstart = <iptables> -N f2b-<name>
              <iptables> -A f2b-<name> -j <returntype>
              <iptables> -I <chain> -p <protocol> -m multiport --dports <port> -j f2b-<name>

# Option:  actionstop
# Notes.:  command executed at the stop of jail (or at the end of Fail2Ban)
# Values:  CMD
#
actionstop = <iptables> -D <chain> -p <protocol> -m multiport --dports <port> -j f2b-<name>
             <actionflush>
             <iptables> -X f2b-<name>

# Option:  actioncheck
# Notes.:  command executed once before each actionban command
# Values:  CMD
#
actioncheck = <iptables> -n -L <chain> | grep -q 'f2b-<name>[ \t]'

# Option:  actionban
# Notes.:  command executed when banning an IP. Take care that the
#          command is executed with Fail2Ban user rights.
# Tags:    See jail.conf(5) man page
# Values:  CMD
#
actionban = <iptables> -I f2b-<name> 1 -s <ip> -p tcp --match multiport --dports 443,80 -j DROP

# Option:  actionunban
# Notes.:  command executed when unbanning an IP. Take care that the
#          command is executed with Fail2Ban user rights.
# Tags:    See jail.conf(5) man page
# Values:  CMD
#
actionunban = <iptables> -D f2b-<name> -s <ip> -p tcp --match multiport --dports 443,80 -j DROP
[Init]

```

/etc/fail2ban/filter.d/haproxy.conf

[INCLUDES]
before = common.conf
[Definition]

_daemon = haproxy

# Option:  failregex
# Notes.:  regex to match the password failures messages in the logfile. The
#          host must be matched by a group named "host". The tag "<HOST>" can

Possible causes and troubleshooting steps:
1. HAProxy Configuration Issues:
Incorrect timeouts: If the timeout client, timeout server, or timeout http-request settings are too low, HAProxy might prematurely close connections, leading to hangs. 
Insufficient connection limits: If HAProxy can't handle the number of concurrent connections, it can cause delays or even complete unavailability. 
Misconfigured keep-alive: Improper use of keep-alive connections can lead to idle connections that don't release resources, potentially impacting performance. 
Invalid or complex configuration: Incorrect syntax or complex configurations can cause HAProxy to behave unexpectedly.
